trans-unit.source: This document contains many elements with optional end tags, server-side tags and some common illegal HTML constructs to demonstrate how they are interpreted by the parser.

trans-unit.source: Note that the parser does not consider this text to be a part of the paragraph started before the table because according to the HTML specification a TABLE, being a block-level element, must terminate the P element. See the documentation in HTMLElementName.P for more information, including instructions on how to make this parser compatible with the default behaviour of all major browsers in HTML transitional mode.

seg-source.mrk: Note that the parser does not consider this text to be a part of the paragraph started before the table because according to the HTML specification a TABLE, being a block-level element, must terminate the P element. See the documentation in HTMLElementName.P for more information, including instructions on how to make this parser compatible with the default behaviour of all major browsers in HTML transitional mode.

target.mrk: Note that the parser does not consider this text to be a part of the paragraph started before the table because according to the HTML specification a TABLE, being a block-level element, must terminate the P element. See the documentation in HTMLElementName.P for more information, including instructions on how to make this parser compatible with the default behaviour of all major browsers in HTML transitional mode.

trans-unit.source: The P element is only ignored by the parser if a full sequential parse is performed, which ignores any non-server tags inside SCRIPT elements.

trans-unit.source: This P element is ignored by the parser in parse-on-demand mode because of the enclosing CDATA section.

seg-source.mrk: This P element is ignored by the parser in parse-on-demand mode because of the enclosing CDATA section.

target.mrk: This P element is ignored by the parser in parse-on-demand mode because of the enclosing CDATA section.

trans-unit.source: Both the P element and the CDATA section are ignored by the parser during a full sequental parse, which automatically treats script element content as CDATA.

trans-unit.source: This section demonstrates the consequences of illegally nesting block-level elements inside inline-level elements, which is a very common situation caused by the misuse of FONT elements by <FONT face=Arial size=2>HTML editors.

seg-source.mrk: This section demonstrates the consequences of illegally nesting block-level elements inside inline-level elements, which is a very common situation caused by the misuse of FONT elements by <FONT face=Arial size=2>HTML editors.

target.mrk: This section demonstrates the consequences of illegally nesting block-level elements inside inline-level elements, which is a very common situation caused by the misuse of FONT elements by <FONT face=Arial size=2>HTML editors.

trans-unit.source: This paragraph starts inside the Arial FONT element.</FONT> This text occurs after the Arial FONT end tag, but is still considered to be part of the same paragraph.

trans-unit.source: Limitations when dealing with tags located inside other tags

seg-source.mrk: Limitations when dealing with tags located inside other tags

target.mrk: Limitations when dealing with tags located inside other tags

trans-unit.source: This section demonstrates the limitation of the library in distinguishing whether a tag is located inside another tag without a full sequential parse. When a full sequential parse hasn't been performed, the H2 element in the following button's onclick attribute erroneously terminates the current paragraph, and is also returned by tag search methods. See parsing rule 2(i) in the documentation of the Tag class for an explanation.

seg-source.mrk: This section demonstrates the limitation of the library in distinguishing whether a tag is located inside another tag without a full sequential parse. When a full sequential parse hasn't been performed, the H2 element in the following button's onclick attribute erroneously terminates the current paragraph, and is also returned by tag search methods. See parsing rule 2(i) in the documentation of the Tag class for an explanation.

target.mrk: This section demonstrates the limitation of the library in distinguishing whether a tag is located inside another tag without a full sequential parse. When a full sequential parse hasn't been performed, the H2 element in the following button's onclick attribute erroneously terminates the current paragraph, and is also returned by tag search methods. See parsing rule 2(i) in the documentation of the Tag class for an explanation.

trans-unit.source: This anchor element demonstrates that a tag ending in /> is not considered an empty element tag if it has a name that requires an end tag. In this case the final '/' is included in the href attribute value instead of being interpreted as the end of the tag.

seg-source.mrk: This anchor element demonstrates that a tag ending in /> is not considered an empty element tag if it has a name that requires an end tag. In this case the final '/' is included in the href attribute value instead of being interpreted as the end of the tag.

target.mrk: This anchor element demonstrates that a tag ending in /> is not considered an empty element tag if it has a name that requires an end tag. In this case the final '/' is included in the href attribute value instead of being interpreted as the end of the tag.

trans-unit.source: The same goes for tags that have an optional end tag like this paragraph, which has a grey background despite the fact that the p element is syntactically an empty element tag.

seg-source.mrk: The same goes for tags that have an optional end tag like this paragraph, which has a grey background despite the fact that the p element is syntactically an empty element tag.

target.mrk: The same goes for tags that have an optional end tag like this paragraph, which has a grey background despite the fact that the p element is syntactically an empty element tag.

seg-source.mrk: Microsoft Conditional Comments

target.mrk: Microsoft Conditional Comments

trans-unit.source: This paragraph is inside a non-validating downlevel-revealed conditional comment which only appears in browsers other than IE because they ignore the invalid tags surrounding it.

seg-source.mrk: This paragraph is inside a non-validating downlevel-revealed conditional comment which only appears in browsers other than IE because they ignore the invalid tags surrounding it.

target.mrk: This paragraph is inside a non-validating downlevel-revealed conditional comment which only appears in browsers other than IE because they ignore the invalid tags surrounding it.

trans-unit.source: This is an example of a validating downlevel-revealed conditional comment, which hides the invalid conditional tags inside HTML comments. This form must be used if the condition can be true in some IE browsers.

seg-source.mrk: This is an example of a validating downlevel-revealed conditional comment, which hides the invalid conditional tags inside HTML comments. This form must be used if the condition can be true in some IE browsers.

target.mrk: This is an example of a validating downlevel-revealed conditional comment, which hides the invalid conditional tags inside HTML comments. This form must be used if the condition can be true in some IE browsers.

trans-unit.source: This is an example of a slightly simplified validating downlevel-revealed conditional comment that can be used only for the condition !IE (to display in any browser except IE).

seg-source.mrk: This is an example of a slightly simplified validating downlevel-revealed conditional comment that can be used only for the condition !IE (to display in any browser except IE).

target.mrk: This is an example of a slightly simplified validating downlevel-revealed conditional comment that can be used only for the condition !IE (to display in any browser except IE).

trans-unit.source:
<%= $variable %> <%=var%> <%abc=def%> <%
	for (int i=0; i<10; i++) {
		document.write("This is indented server code");
	}
%> <%@ include file="relativeFragment.jsp" %>

trans-unit.source: The following is Mason server code sampled from the Mason book, chapter 2, section 3.4.9:

seg-source.mrk: The following is Mason server code sampled from the Mason book, chapter 2, section 3.4.9:

target.mrk: The following is Mason server code sampled from the Mason book, chapter 2, section 3.4.9:

trans-unit.source: <& menu &> <&| /i18n/itext, lang => $lang &> %# The bits in here will be available from $m->content in the /i18/text Hello, <% $name %>. These words are in English. Bonjour, <% $name %>, ces mots sont franE<#xC3>E<#xA7>ais. Ellohay <% substr($name,2) . substr($name,0,1) . 'ay' %>, esethay ordsway areyay inyay Igpay Atinlay. <%def .make_a_link> <% $text %> <%args> $path %query => ( ) $text <%init> my $url = ... ... <*abc def="ghi"> This is an example of an element from a hypothetical server language whose tag formats have not been registered with the TagTypeRegister class

seg-source.mrk: <& menu &> <&| /i18n/itext, lang => $lang &> %# The bits in here will be available from $m->content in the /i18/text Hello, <% $name %>. These words are in English. Bonjour, <% $name %>, ces mots sont franE<#xC3>E<#xA7>ais. Ellohay <% substr($name,2) . substr($name,0,1) . 'ay' %>, esethay ordsway areyay inyay Igpay Atinlay. <%def .make_a_link> <% $text %> <%args> $path %query => ( ) $text <%init> my $url = ... ... <*abc def="ghi"> This is an example of an element from a hypothetical server language whose tag formats have not been registered with the TagTypeRegister class

'ay' %>, esethay ordsway areyay inyay Igpay Atinlay. <%def .make_a_link> <% $text %> <%args> $path %query => ( ) $text <%init> my $url = ... ... <*abc def="ghi"> This is an example of an element from a hypothetical server language whose tag formats have not been registered with the TagTypeRegister class
